results.title: Working together
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
Regional and international co-operation of scientists ad governments in the development of peaceful se of atomic energy; and some of the achievements of this co-operation, sch as the flow of isotopes from one country to another, the transfer of fissionable materials for research purposes, and the establishment of international centres for atomic research. From the series “Atoms for peace”.

results.title: Medicine
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
Shows uses of atomic materials in medical research and diagnosis; illustrates, through a sequence involving a brain tumour, the use of radioactive materials as tracers in the detection and location of disease; and describes atomic research in the treatment of hyperthyroidism, cancer and arteriosclerosis.

results.title: ScooterZ: basics and beyond
results.brief_description: Presented by Eric Wiley, this short program with an energetic soundtrack shows beginners and advanced riders enjoying their ScooterZ - a mode of transport originating in Asia that has taken the world by storm. Everything from young boys getting about town, Razer Pro Team Riders, Go-PED Pro Team Riders and professional rollerbladers, in line skaters and other extreme forms of “board” sports. NB: This is not an instructional video, and not all riders wear helmets and knee pads. Rather it shows the possibilities of ScooterZ and the progression from skate boards to in line skating to ScooterZ and beyond.

results.title: Farming: Soviet style
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Soviet style”.
Examines the Soviet agricultural system, the collective farms, or Kolkhoz, the State farms, or Sovkhoz and the importance of the agricultural private plot. Credits include: photography by Dean Semler; script by Roger Milliss; edited by Martyn Down; sound by Howard Spry and commentary by Margaret Throsby.

results.title: Scoggie
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Scott and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: While most of Cape Breton’s youth leave for the excitement and opportunity of the big cities, twenty-seven-year-old Scoggie Watson remains, clinging to the things he cherishes most: the waters of Lake Bras d’Or, his hand-built sailboat, his freedom, and the friends who stayed behind. This is his story. It is a story that includes the hearty determination of some of the island people, a government scheme to develop marine farming on the Bras d’Or Lakes, and a mysterious stranger who has remained Scoggie’s hero since he was fourteen years old. Commentary by Donald Brittain.

results.title: Politics: Soviet style
results.creator_credit: David Brownlow, Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A brief history of politics in Russia prior to the Revolution in 1917, through the leadership of Lenin and Stalin, into the 1970’s. Identifies the Communist Party as the source of ultimate power and attempts to explain party organisation. Photography is by Dean Semler and narration by Margaret Throsby. Suitable for secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Brownlow, Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia

results.title: The People's music: Soviet style
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Russian Education”.
Contains eleven examples of Soviet citizens engaged in making music. Ranges from kindergarten children in Minst singing and dancing a traditional folk song to the highly respected professional group, the Kuban Cossack Choir and the Veryovka Folk Ensemble. Photographer, Dean Semler; script, Roger Milliss; editor, Martyn Down; sound, George Hart, Howard Spry; commentator, Margaret Throsby.

results.title: School's in, Soviet style
results.creator_credit: Martyn Down, Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Russian Education”.
Examines the present school system in the Soviet Union. Demonstrates the style of Soviet teaching which is fairly rigid and formal, with the emphasis on teacher dominated instruction and passive pupils, responding only when instructed to do so. A more flexible teaching style was introduced some years ago but was later abandoned. Photographer, Dean Semler; script, Roger Milliss; editor, Martyn Down; sound, George Hart, Howard Spry; commentator, Margaret Throsby.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Martyn Down, Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
